file_metadata.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]
file_metadata.title: Membrane potential depolarization causes alterations in neuron arrangement and connectivity in cocultures

chunks.text: Membrane potential depolarization causes alterations in neuron arrangement and connectivity in cocultures. The disruption of neuron arrangement is associated with several pathologies. In contrast to action potentials, the role of resting potential (Vmem) in regulating connectivity remains unknown. Neuron assemblies were quantified when their Vmem was depolarized using ivermectin (Ivm), a drug that opens chloride channels, for 24 h in cocultures with astrocytes. Cell aggregation was analyzed using automated cluster analysis methods. Neural connectivity was quantified based on the identification of isolated somas in phase-contrast images using image processing. Vmem was measured using voltage-sensitive dyes and whole-cell patch clamping. Immunocytochemistry and Western blotting were used to detect changes in the distribution and production of the proteins. Data show that Vmem regulates cortical tissue shape and connectivity. Automated cluster analysis methods revealed that the degree of neural aggregation was significantly increased (0.26 clustering factor vs. 0.21 in controls, P < 0.01). The number of beta-tubulin III positive neural projections was also significantly increased in the neural aggregates in cocultures with Ivm. Hyperpolarized neuron cells formed fewer connections (33% at 24 h, P < 0.05) compared to control cells in 1-day cultures. Glia cell densities increased (33.3%, P ≤ 0.05) under depolarizing conditions. Vmem can be a useful tool to probe neuronal cells, disease tissues models, and cortical tissue arrangements.
chunks.chunk_summary: Resting membrane potential (Vmem) regulates cortical tissue shape and connectivity, with depolarization increasing neural aggregation and glial cell density, while hyperpolarization decreases connections in immature neurons.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Cortical arrangement, including shape and size at the cellular and tissue levels, relates to neural connectivity associated with normal brain development and function. Neural assemblies are diffuse structures comprising cells in the cortex and diencephalon capable of acting briefly as a closed system, delivering facilitation to other such systems. They are implicated in complex brain functions such as learning or planning, and accepted as the smallest representatives of a cognitive concept in the brain, as explained in Hebbian theory. Neural assemblies are suggested to constitute neural syntaxes that integrate and parse the fundamental assemblies of neural activities. Deficits in neuronal organization and connectivity can result in a range of pathologies, including corticobasal syndrome, autism, epilepsy, Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, and social anxiety disorder. The deformation or volume change in cortical tissue occurs in several neurological diseases, such as dementia, Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, and schizophrenia. Brain morphometric studies have revealed focal abnormalities in several areas of the brain, including the cortex, in schizophrenia patients. Volume loss and cortical thinning were found in the medial temporal lobe of individuals with schizophrenia when compared with control groups. Also, correlations between structural measures and memory performance in schizophrenia subjects were demonstrated. Significant variations in shape have been reported in the frontobasal brain region in Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder. Reductions in cortical thickness in the left hemisphere and a lack of integrity of white matter is a main contributor to long-term impairment in declarative memory among patients suffering from severe and diffuse traumatic brain injury. A recent study verified that cortical thinning is observable/quantifiable and is functionally relevant in blast-related traumatic brain injury patients. Interestingly, regardless of the disease-induced cause, a decline in cortex volume has also been identified in elderly. However, it is still not known which cell types in number, density, or size in the brain are disturbed related to neurological disorders.
chunks.chunk_summary: Disruptions in neuronal organization and connectivity are implicated in various neurological disorders, affecting cortical shape, volume, and cognitive function.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of clinical subjects is the most common approach used to assess functional brain anatomy. This analytical approach provides rapid and general diagnosis for clinical purposes, but lacks spatial resolution at the cellular level, which is important to elucidate the mechanisms of disease and development. In vitro model systems and automated quantitative analysis tools are needed to achieve insight into disease mechanisms and to implement approaches for disease control and therapy. Vmem can regulate cell differentiation as undifferentiated cells exhibit relatively depolarized Vmem compared to terminally differentiated cells. The underlying mechanism for that is the regulation of cell proliferation and differentiation. It has long been known that activity of the nervous system during embryogenesis helps regulate differentiation, proliferation, and topology of the nascent CNS. However, despite the exciting recent data indicating roles for resting potential gradients in embryonic patterning of many organs, the roles of Vmem in neural connectivity remain unknown. The objective of this study was to develop a novel approach to mimic and detect abnormalities in cortical tissue arrangement based on changes in the neuron arrangement, as well as shape and size of neural cell assemblies. Ivm is known to change the cellular chloride content. Ivm can change the Vmem specifically by binding to Glycine Receptor Chloride Channel alpha-1 subunit. That makes Ivm a specifically targeted and a convenient tool to change the Vmem in cells expressing the channel. We found that Ivm can affect both astrocytes and neurons, as western blot studies revealed that GlyR was produced also in astrocytes. However, the ability of Ivm to affect Vmem was in different time windows for neurons and astrocytes. Ivm caused a relatively hyperpolarized Vmem in astrocytes alone at 2w and 4w where it reversed neuron Vmem (depolarized) at 3 weeks in presence of astrocytes versus the controls. Using intrinsic chloride-dependent Vmem shift from depolarizing to hyperpolarizing in developing neurons, cortical shape and connectivity were controlled with a Vmem-specific manner using Ivm. The data reveal that changes in gross cortical anatomy can be recapitulated at the cellular level, and suggest Vmem as a useful tool to establish in vitro models for both normal and diseased cortex.
chunks.chunk_summary: Vmem regulates cell differentiation and plays a role in neural connectivity, and Ivermectin (Ivm) can be used to manipulate Vmem and study its effects on cortical tissue arrangement in vitro.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: E18 rat cerebral cortical tissue was used. The brain tissue isolation protocol was approved by Tufts University Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee and complies with the NIH Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals. Cortices were enzymatically dissociated using trypsin and DNase, then centrifuged and resuspended. Cells were seeded on poly-d-lysine coated plates in Neurobasal Media supplemented with B27, penicillin/streptomycin, and glutamax. Ivm was added to the culture medium to change Vmem. Cell culture media were changed once a week. Ninety-six-well plates, 8-well chambers, and 3-cm petri dishes were used for high-throughput measurements, immunocytochemistry, and connectivity assays, respectively.
chunks.chunk_summary: E18 rat cortical neurons were cultured in vitro with Ivm added to manipulate Vmem.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Cortices were homogenized and passed through a 40 µm cell strainer. Cells were cultured in 10% FBS DMEM with penicillin/streptomycin, then switched to 2% FBS DMEM after one week. Neurons and astrocytes were seeded in a 3:1 ratio for cocultures. Cocultures were maintained in astrocyte media combined with complete neurobasal media. Medium was changed once a week. Astrocyte cultures were split 1:5 once a week.
chunks.chunk_summary: Rat astroglial cells were isolated and cultured, then co-cultured with neurons in a 3:1 ratio.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Cell toxicity was assessed using the WST-1 assay, which measures mitochondrial activity. Cultures were incubated with WST-1 reagent, and mitochondrial dehydrogenase activity was measured as optical density at 440 nm. Cell viability was represented as optical density values divided by corresponding cell numbers.
chunks.chunk_summary: The WST-1 assay was used to measure cell viability by assessing mitochondrial activity.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Cells were fixed, permeabilized, and incubated with primary antibodies overnight, followed by fluorescence-coupled secondary antibodies.  Fluoroshield Mounting Medium with DAPI was used. Antibodies used included Vimentin, GFAP, Glycine Receptor Alpha 1 (GLRA1), Synaptophysin, beta III-tubulin, anti-mouse Alexa Fluor 568, anti-rabbit Alexa Fluor 488, and Hoechst 33342. Images were collected using a Leica DM inverted fluorescence microscope.
chunks.chunk_summary: Immunocytochemistry was performed using various antibodies to label specific cell types and proteins.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Cell lysates were boiled in sample buffer, loaded into SDS-PAGE gels, and run at 80V for 30 min, then 150V for 1-2 h. Protein was transferred to PVDF membrane, blocked, and incubated with primary antibody overnight or for 2 h. After washing, the membrane was incubated with labeled secondary antibody, washed again, and soaked in ECL western blotting substrate for signal development. Imaging was performed after covering the membrane in transparent plastic wrap.
chunks.chunk_summary: Western blotting was performed to analyze protein expression levels.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Ratiometric di-8-ANEPPS dye was used to measure Vmem of neurons, astrocytes, and cocultures. Cells were stained with the dye, incubated, and washed. Fluorescent intensities were measured using a SpectraMax M5 multiplate reader. Relative Vmem was measured as the ratio of readings at two excitation states (450 nm/510 nm, emission: 640 nm).
chunks.chunk_summary: Vmem was measured using the di-8-ANEPPS voltage-sensitive dye.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Cultured cortical neurons were placed in a recording chamber containing extracellular solution. Membrane potentials were measured using whole-cell patch clamping with an Axopatch 1D amplifier in current-clamp mode. Patch electrodes were filled with intracellular solution. Data were filtered and digitized using pClamp 10 software. Vmem quantification based on both di-8-ANEPPS and whole-cell patch clamping revealed that a 1% change in ANEPPS ratio corresponds to a 1 mV change in Vmem.
chunks.chunk_summary: Whole-cell patch clamping was used to measure membrane potential, and a calibration between dye and patch clamp measurements was established.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: A Fourier-based analysis of image intensities was used to quantify cell clustering. Images were resampled and cropped. A 2D power spectral density (PSD) map was obtained through a discrete Fourier transform, and radially sampled to produce a PSD-frequency curve.  A PSD-weighted average spatial frequency (f) and a normalized clustering factor (NCF) were calculated. NCF values were obtained from each fluorescence channel.
chunks.chunk_summary: A Fourier-based method was used to analyze cell clustering using a normalized clustering factor (NCF).
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Cells were counted by identifying DAPI-stained nuclei. Pixel intensity values were normalized, and filtered images were produced to highlight nuclei. A Prewitt edge finding filter was applied. Nuclei were labeled as neurons or astrocytes based on the intensity of green (beta III tubulin) and red (GFAP) channels. The relative areas covered by astrocytes and neurons were calculated based on channel intensities. Average cell area was computed from the total area covered by cells of that type divided by the number of cells. Cell densities were computed from the number of cells divided by the total image area.
chunks.chunk_summary: Automated image analysis algorithms were used to count cells, estimate cell area, and calculate cell densities based on DAPI staining and cell-type specific markers.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Depolarization of Vmem in mature neurons caused increased neural aggregation and glial cell density. Automated cluster analysis showed a significant increase in neural aggregation (0.26 clustering factor vs. 0.21 in controls). The number of beta-tubulin III positive neural projections also increased significantly in the neural aggregates. Glial cell densities increased (33.3%) under depolarizing conditions. This increase may be due to growth factors released from depolarized neurons or increased metabolic demands. The increased density of glia cells may also be due to the change in the microenvironment caused by the higher density packing of astrocytes surrounding neurons.
chunks.chunk_summary: Depolarization of mature neurons led to increased neural aggregation, increased beta-tubulin III positive projections, and increased glial cell density.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Neural connectivity was assessed by quantifying neurite outgrowth and contact between neuron somas. Immature neurons in 1-day cultures were assessed under normal and depolarizing conditions (after Ivm exposure). Vmem was measured using di-8-ANEPPS dye. Immature neurons were characterized using vimentin and GFAP markers. Phase-contrast images were collected before and after Ivm exposure. The ratio of total somas to isolated somas was manually counted.  Neural connectivity was significantly suppressed at each time point in Ivm-exposed samples. The ratio of total soma number to isolated soma decreased significantly at 0, 2, 4, 6, and 24 h by 28%, 25%, 16%, 21%, and 33%, respectively.  Cells were labeled with beta-III tubulin, Synaptophysin, and Glycine receptor alpha (GLRA) for axon outgrowth, pre-, and postsynaptic proteins, respectively. Ivm-treated cells had thin, discontinuous projections, while control cells had continuous, thick bundles. Ivm-treated neurons did not show Synaptophysin, while control cells had dense synaptic areas positive for the protein. GLRA was not detected along projections of Ivm-treated neurons but only in somas, while control cells had strong GLRA production along projections and in somas. Membrane potential hyperpolarization caused a decrease in neuron connectivity.
chunks.chunk_summary: Hyperpolarization of immature neurons resulted in decreased neural connectivity, evidenced by reduced neurite outgrowth and synaptic protein expression.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: The pancreas has exocrine and endocrine functions. The exocrine function involves producing digestive enzymes like trypsin, chymotrypsin, amylase, and lipase, which are released into the duodenum via the pancreatic duct. The endocrine function involves islet cells releasing hormones like insulin and glucagon into the bloodstream to regulate blood sugar.
chunks.chunk_summary: The pancreas has both exocrine (digestive enzyme production) and endocrine (hormone release) functions.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Vmem plays a critical role in the arrangement of neurons and glia in vitro. Depolarization of Vmem in mature neurons caused an increase in the number of projections, whereas hyperpolarization of Vmem in immature neurons caused a decrease in the number of connections. These findings suggest that Vmem may be a key regulator of neuronal and glial cell morphology and connectivity.
chunks.chunk_summary: Vmem is a key regulator of neuronal and glial arrangement, with depolarization increasing projections in mature neurons and hyperpolarization decreasing connections in immature neurons.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Depolarization of Vmem in mature neurons caused an increase in glial cell density, consistent with previous studies. This may be due to growth factors released from depolarized neurons or increased metabolic demands. Changes in Vmem affect cell proliferation, migration, and differentiation. Depolarization may activate voltage-gated calcium channels, leading to calcium influx and activation of signaling pathways promoting neurite outgrowth.
chunks.chunk_summary: Depolarization of mature neurons increases glial cell density, potentially due to growth factor release or increased metabolic demands, and affects various cellular processes including neurite outgrowth.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: The observed neuronal clustering may be due to increased expression of cell adhesion molecules (CAMs). Depolarization of Vmem increases CAM expression, which may promote clustering by increasing cell-cell adhesion. The increase in glial cell density may be due to the release of growth factors from neurons, stimulated by Vmem depolarization.
chunks.chunk_summary: Neuronal clustering may be caused by increased CAM expression due to Vmem depolarization, and increased glial cell density may be due to growth factor release from neurons.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Vmem is involved in neurotransmitter release, ion channel gating, and synaptic plasticity.  These findings suggest that Vmem also plays a role in regulating the morphology and connectivity of neurons and glia. Further studies are needed to investigate the mechanisms by which Vmem regulates these processes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Vmem plays a role in various neuronal processes, including morphology and connectivity regulation, and further research is needed to understand the underlying mechanisms.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Cortical size and shape are clinical measures for functional brain disorders. Many disorders can be diagnosed using volumetric measurements, including fMRI and PET scans. However, these tools lack cellular-level resolution needed to understand the mechanisms of anatomical abnormalities. Understanding the cell physiological basis of brain diseases is crucial for characterizing disorders and establishing realistic in vitro models for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. This study shows that Vmem can change cortical tissue arrangement, shape, size, and neural connectivity in vitro. Mature cortical neurons aggregated and formed assemblies when their Vmem was depolarized. These assemblies varied in size. Hypotheses for the molecular signatures of neuron assemblies are mostly characterized based on firing patterns. Membrane potential regulation of cell connectivity is an area of ongoing research.
chunks.chunk_summary: Vmem influences cortical tissue arrangement, shape, size, and connectivity in vitro, offering a potential tool for studying brain disorders at the cellular level.
chunks.authors: ["Murdan Golcuk", "Kyle P. Quinn", "Jin C. Pang", "Chuang Du", "Irene Georgakoudi", "Eric Miller", "Michael Levin", "David L. Kaplan"]
